Author: Regnar#6164
Content: Hey just thinking about the whole point of a DEX being to have p2p trading and prevent censorship, maybe we should offer versions of BarterDEX downloadable as torrents?

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: I mean, it doesn't need to be an official thing, but it could be useful for us to get an official Komodo account on PirateBay to host BarterDEX. That way when people download it they can trust the version they get from the Komodo account?

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: as opposed to just downloading it from some random person hosting it.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: And then we just update it with the newest versions as they come out. I'm not sure how effective it would be at bypassing censors seeing as they likely block piratebay, but there are dozens of PB mirror sites that can get by. And I'm sure if a country tries to crack down on downloading this type of stuff they'd likely start by cracking down on github, and crypto sites like Komodo

If they can't modify the code and still seed it as the original then it shouldn't be a problem.

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: I've been giving it some thought and initially I thought it would be simpler to just fork the dash dashboard but there are many factors that wouldn't fit to the Komodo ecosystem. We would need to come up with a proposal mechanism. In dash, you have master nodes with voting power and users can vote by vouching funds. It's all done through multisig so the funds can be returned if it falls through or if funds need to be re-allocated

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Aside from the technical aspect of repurposing the dashboard, we would have to explore ways of encouraging voting and participation.

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Maybe we can include notary nodes as entities with proposal Power..... Not sure yet

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
I'm iffy on ads. I think we should (and we are currently doing this process) first establish what it is our goals and measure of successes are. This could be increase in price (not a great one imo) user adoption (as currency),  launch more dICOs, launch more ACs (businesses or projects), migrate tokens to KMD AC, etc. but find which segment we are best suited to cater to, is attractive for adoption and the ecosystem, and is an opportunity for growth in both users and developers. 

Only then should we re-position our branding, tech, and focus to cater to these solutions (not excluding the other segments) and then find out the best way to target advertisement and marketing towards actual segments. For example, ad space on an exchange landing page could help traders buy KMD and increase price, but if our target segment is say, AC migration, we would be much better off spending money sending reps to coin meetups where other dev teams will be there in person.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
Based on a focused plan and target segment we should be able to actually measure the cost of every increase in our metrics when measuring our success. For example, a $5000 ad on CMC may show us click through and we can try to associate it to a measurable increase in say "user adoption" or price, but that would be a reach of an argument. On the other hand $5000 for a table and airfare + hotel at a blockchain conference in which we get a commitment from an erc20 token to migrate to Komodo, or a business that wants to use an AC to build an audit/notary base. Would be measurable to split those costs.

It comes down to what we WANT to accomplish, as in the main goal we want to focus on or problem we are trying to solve, the segment that is having those problems, and how do we get in front of them to show our solutions. The measure of success isn't always shown in price either, but increased network effect and ecosystem breadth can lead to greater prices later.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: But again, this is what is being done. It takes time and rebranding isn't easy. It's also important to realize that if we (as individual investors) are not the target segment, our avenues likely won't see the marketing efforts targeted towards that segment. unless we look for it, or someone shows us
